metadata.case_name: N. S. Anirudhan v. Thomcos Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Bank agreed to allow an overdraft to defendant No. 1 (Shankaran/V. Sankaran) for Rs. 20,000/-
Appellant (N.S. Anirudhan) gave a surety bond/letter of guarantee for the repayment of Rs. 25,000/-
Defendant No. 1/principal debtor (Sankaran) made the alteration in the document by reducing the figure of Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/-
Appellant claimed he stood surety originally for Rs. 5,000/- which was altered to Rs. 20,000/- without his consent
Trial court found original amount Rs. 25,000/- altered to Rs. 20,000/- without appellant's consent, dismissed suit against appellant

High Court of Kerala agreed original was Rs. 25,000/- altered to Rs. 20,000/- probably by Sankaran, but held alteration carried out common intention, decreed against appellant relying on s.87 Negotiable Instruments Act
Sankaran executed promissory note for Rs. 20,000/- on February 24, 1947
Letter of guarantee typed by Bank with blanks, taken by Sankaran, returned with Rs. 25,000/- filled, Bank refused as wanted only Rs. 20,000/-, returned to Sankaran who altered it
Suit decreed against Sankaran by trial court, no appeal by him
Original letter shows corrections: figure 5 altered to O in Rs. 20,000/-, word 'five' struck out in 'Rupees twenty five thousand'

legal_issues.text: Whether the alteration of the letter of guarantee from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- without the surety's consent constitutes a material alteration that avoids the contract and discharges the surety
Whether the alteration carries out the common intention of the parties and is immaterial as it reduces the surety's liability

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant never stood surety for Rs. 20,000/-; any change of figure was a material alteration resulting in avoidance of the contract, even if advantageous
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Unauthorised material alteration avoids contract (Halsbury's Laws of England)

petitioner_arguments.text: Originally guaranteed Rs. 5,000/- altered to Rs. 20,000/- without consent, material alteration absolves liability

respondent_arguments.text: Alteration from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- is not material as it reduces liability and is beneficial; no prejudice to surety
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England; alteration not material unless to prejudice

respondent_arguments.text: Alteration carries out common intention for overdraft of Rs. 20,000/-; principle of s.87 Negotiable Instruments Act applies by analogy
Sankaran acted as agent of guarantor; estoppel prevents plea of unauthorised alteration

court_reasoning.text: Document altered by principal debtor acting as agent of guarantor; avoidance by material alteration inapplicable as not in possession of promisee
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea of material alteration of no avail

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of mistake in writing Rs. 25,000/-; alteration not to carry out intention apparent on face of deed; s.87 NIA principle inapplicable
Even if alteration ignored, original for Rs. 25,000/- not accepted by Bank; no contract for Rs. 20,000/- proved
Alteration not material as reduces liability beneficially; surety's case of Rs. 5,000/- disbelieved; Sankaran had authority as agent, estoppel
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document continues to represent intention to guarantee up to Rs. 25,000/- which includes Rs. 20,000/-

holdings.text: Material alteration by principal debtor acting as surety's agent does not discharge surety; alteration from 25,000 to 20,000 not material as beneficial
Unsubstantial alterations beneficial to surety do not discharge liability

precedents_cited.relevance: Principle applies to instruments under hand; alteration carrying out intention
Intention must be with which instrument executed, apparent on face
Correction of mistake made in drawing bill

precedents_cited.case_name: Ananda Mohan Saha v. Ananda Chandra Naha

precedents_cited.relevance: Surety bound to letter of engagement; alteration ends obligation
Unsubstantial or beneficial alterations do not discharge surety

precedents_cited.case_name: Ward v. National Bank of New Zealand Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved Cotton L.J. in Holme v. Brunskill
Strict rule on any alteration; tempered in later cases

precedents_cited.case_name: Bishop of Crediton v. Bishop of Exeter

precedents_cited.relevance: Mutilation of bank note number vital

precedents_cited.case_name: Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation v. Lo Lee Khi
precedents_cited.relevance: Alteration of bank note not avoiding if contract remains

statutes_cited.name: Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881
statutes_cited.relevance: Material alteration of negotiable instrument; principle of wider application but inapplicable here as letter of guarantee not negotiable

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Inadequacy of consideration does not avoid contract; past consideration supports guarantee

outcome.summary: Appeal by the surety (appellant) against the High Court decree holding him liable on the altered letter of guarantee dismissed by majority (Kapur and Hidayatullah JJ.; Sarkar J. dissenting). Suit against appellant upheld.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree against appellant as guarantor for Rs. 20,000/- stands
outcome.costs: Kapur J.: no order as to costs; Sarkar J.: costs here and below

key_quotes.text: "Now an unauthorised material alteration avoids a contract so that if a promisee after a written contract has been executed materially alters it without the consent of the promisor ... the contract is avoided"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States general rule on material alteration (Kapur J.)

key_quotes.text: "A surety is considered a favoured debtor and his liability is strictissimi juris."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes strict liability of surety (Hidayatullah J.)

key_quotes.text: "The true rule ... is, that if there is any agreement between the principals with reference to the contract guaranteed, the surety ought to be consulted, and that if he has not consented to the alteration, although ... unsubstantial, or ... beneficial to the surety, the surety may not be discharged"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Qualifies strict rule for beneficial alterations (Hidayatullah J. quoting Holme v. Brunskill)
